doc.field: President Herzog invites Russia to a Partnership for Future

On the occasion of a state visit in Russia German President Roman Herzog has praised Russia's progress and invited Russia to a close and friendly co-operation with Germany. If Germany and Russia collaborated confidently in all areas this would develop into a partnership for the 21st century, Herzog said in his speech that was broadcast by Russian television. In his speech Herzog also assured Russia of Germany's support for the reform process.
No right on asylum when refugees enter Germany by land

The Federal Administrative Court in Berlin has ruled that a foreigner who enters Germany by land cannot apply for asylum. The court rejected the asylum applications of several Turkish Kurds who have come to Germany in a closed and sealed truck. The court argued that all neighbour states of Germany were safe states where the refugees could have found protection from persecution. If a foreigner did not use this opportunity he or she could neither be granted asylum in Germany.
Kurds apprehended who illegally entered Germany

In August 394 Kurds from Iraq have been apprehended at the French border close to the Kehl port of entry. They had entered Germany illegally. The Border Guards said the Kurds had stayed mostly in the Offenburg and Baden-Baden area.
SPD warns against climate disaster

Social Democrats have warned against a climate phenomenon called "El Nino". El Nino is created by a strong warming of the Pacific Ocean at the South-American coast causing winds and sea currents to change directions. As a consequence, some areas are affected by drought, others by flooding. SPD environmental politicians think that El Nino will not spare Europe and predict heavy storms and rains next year. The Social-Democrats demand that if necessary the government should act on its own to reduce the greenhouse effect. Especially, it was necessary to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide.
Trial against West German border guards about shootings at the Wall

Today, the Regional Court in Berlin started the trial against two West German border guards who are accused of attempted murder of a border patrol of the former GDR at the Berlin wall in summer 1970. The soldiers allegedly shot the patrol.
Krenz' attorneys complain against incarceration

The attorneys of Egon Krenz, former head of the East German Communist party and leader of the country, have protested against his incarceration. They argue that there was zero probability that Krenz would attempt to flee. The 60-year-old former GDR politician had been sentenced to six and a half years in prison for the shootings at the German-German border. The sentence has not become effective yet.
Salary tables in public service too complicated

The Federal Labour Court considers the regulations for salaries in the public service too complicated. The Court in Kassel found that the employer was not responsible if he accidentally put employees into the wrong salary group. The judges decided that a public employer would have to pay partial interest only if the grouping was into a group with a lower salary.
Number of student subsidy applications continue to decline

Fewer and fewer students apply for BAFoeG [a combined loan-scholarship by the federal government for students of low-income families]. The Federal Department of Statistics reported that the number of applicants declined by 46,000 compared to 1995, or 7.4%. At the same time, the individual grants increased to adjust for inflation. On average, pupils received DM513 per month and university students DM629.
Tabloid press criticized

Germany's yellow press is being increasingly criticized after the tragic death of Princess Diana in an accident after a chase by photographs. The president of the parliamentary justice committee Horst Eylmann said today on NDR that the boulevard press had lost any decency for a long time with their methods of screening the private life of people. Vice-president of the SPD media commission Mr. Junker called for an EU-wide agreement on the basics of journalist ethics.
Anti-trust office concerned about travel sector

The Federal Anti-Trust Office in Berlin is concerned about monopoly tendencies in the tourism sector after Preussag has made public plans to take over the traditional Hapag-Lloyd company. The Anti-Trust Office says that a strong market concentration in the tourism sector could finally lead to price agreements among companies to the detriment of the consumer.
Handicraft companies still offer training jobs

Handicraft companies that traditionally have offered the most training jobs to apprentices have made 3 percent fewer work contracts until August than last year at the same time. Especially in the East the number of training jobs has decreased drastically. Countrywide there are still 20,000 training jobs left, 2000 of them in the Munich area. These apparently include highly desired jobs such as car mechanic and electric contractor.
Large fire in Traunstein District

A fire on a farm in Engelsberg has caused damage worth DM600,000. The fire started in the early hours of the morning and completely destroyed the listed farm. The residential house could be saved from the flames.
Soccer
In a postponed match of the Bundesliga the Munich Lions beat Bielefeld last night 1-0 and thus had the first home victory.
